reviewText:
Well, DreadOut is another flawed game with a good premise, but marred by bugs and poor design choices.  How well do these balance out?  Let's put it this way.  Normally, I list the bad things first so we can end off the review on a positive note.  I'm going the other way around this time because otherwise, you may never see the pros.

Pros: The story.  Actually something different from the usual ghosts just want to kill you".
Great variety of ghosts
date: in large part because they are taken from Asian legends and not the usual North American and European ones.\nPossessed Ira's dialog and actions really stand out. I mean
recommended:
to the point where I wondered if they subcontracted out that part of the game.
Nice variety of ways to deal with the ghosts.
Cons: INCREDIBLY awkward dialog and animations.  I half thought Linda and Ira were already dead or possessed from the way they interacted at the beginning of Act I.
Look
hoursPlayed: I get that Linda's a silent protagonist
voteText: but for the love of all that's holy
helpfulPercent: please work the dialog so that it's not all awkward silences.\nReally bad translations at times\nTranslations for written language (especially signs) would have been nice. I get that we're not in an English speaking country
votesHelpful: but Linda is probably supposed to be able to read Indonesian.  Or is that enabled along with subtitles?\nGhosts that don't act the way their entries say they will.  All those man-hating ghosts?  Not really sure why they're so hostile to Linda.\nIt was definitely unclear to me what I was supposed to do with the camera at first. Act 0 gives you the basic idea that some ghosts only appear there
votesTotal:
but there was no indication that the flash would actually hurt them.  The hint text merely tells you they might be startled.
How slowly Linda move when the camera is up.
How slowly Linda moves the camera up and down. (Lag)
How slowly Linda does anything when ghosts are nearby (Laaaaaaag)
Puzzles with random solutions.  Why that one mirror?  Why not?
The devs really need to rethink their autosave/respawn policy.  In Act 0
votesFunny: I kept respawning to the exact spot I died in
commentsCount: only the enemies were still there. And since Linda took forever to move her camera up (see above)
column16: I couldn't break out of the loop.  I figured I could just reload the save point
column17: but guess what?  It autosaved with the enemies on top of me.  Nothing I could do but replay the entire Act.\nThe stage where there are 4 objects you need to hit the ghost 4 times.  I died after breaking the first object
column18: but when I respawned
column19: the object was already broken
column20: yet the ghost still needed all 4 hits.\nAt one point
column21: I could no longer hurt the Sundel Bolong.  The camera just had no effect whatsoever. Exiting and reloading did nothing. I had to go the rest of the game unable to do anything but run away from her.  Which made boss battles that much more annoying.\nThere are
column22: in fact
column23: times when your survival is entirely a matter of luck. During the locust attack
column24: for example
column25: you are unable to raise your camera
column26: yet are attacked by a ghost that cannot be seen without the camera. Nice.\nThe alternate ending looks like it was thrown together at the last minute.\nInconsistent rules. Invisible barriers are bad enough
column27: but to hit them during a chase sequence?  Grrr.  Why on earth does the SLR flash behave completely differently depending on whether you take a photo or not?\nI dunno
column28: maybe if this franchise is given to more experienced devs
column29: we could have something really good on our hands.  Otherwise
column30: I'm just going to watch somebody else play it on YouTube.  Some games just need more polish.  This one has so little polish

reviewText: This game is really under-rated, and I am completely enjoying it. It feels like a tribute to both Fatal Frame: The Crimson Butterfly and early Silent Hill games. Absolutely worth checking out, especially if you pick it up during a Steam sale. It's entertaining and creepy.

reviewText:
This game is pretty good, I'm big into horror games and its sad to see that so many more modern installments in this genre really fall flat, but this game manages to get out of that rut very well. For any other die hard horror fans this game is very akin to the Fatal Frame/Project Zero games, in terms of gameplay, characters and tone. But it does have a bit of everything, its got the atmoshere of silent hill, the charm of clock tower, the gameplay of fatal frame and a few jumpscares (though for those worried the jumpscares are not too prominent and are put togetehr with the correct amount of timing and atmosphere

Story: 7/10, its develped very well and you really have to search for the whole story, but that doent stop it from being a bit typical in some places.
Gameplay: 7/10, Again it does play nice and the mechanics all work, but there are glitches and camera twitches in places, though nothing too noticable.
SPoOky?: 8/10, in a world where mosthorror games keep you wincing and flintching in preperation for a scare, this does well to keep you on the edge of your seat and terrified.

reviewText:
So much wrong I just don't know where to begin....

Despite the game being a rip off from another early game called Fatal Frame - which was more playable - I thought I would give it a go.

5 hours in and the clumsy controls are still making this game annoying to play. Yes this is a horror game but the only thing scary about it are the nightmarish controls. I've played some badly designed games ( I love indie ) but this is a total crock. OH GOD what was with that phone button, don't hold it long enough and nothing happens, hold it too long and the phone is put away again. WTF for????

I got stuck twice on ghosts (chapter 0 and 1) killing me repeatedly right after I respawned....you respawn in the same spot you die with the ghost still attacking and you can't move. Having to restart due bad design is not fun....hello game designers

I collected items, rings, dolls, newspaper clippings....with no explaination as to how they benefit me.....something vague about mystical power????

The graphics are cutely PS2 level even though this intended orginally for PS4 or PS3. The music is entirely random with some tracks obviously grabbed from 1950's Boris Kaloff The Mummy" movie. I can see why Playstation ended rejecting this game....

I've had this in my collection for a while.....and I wished i had only just payed for it so I could return it.

This sort of game is only for die hard idiots with no life or utter completionists. I noticed how many people on the gaming forums have had to ask for help to get through this .... a total sham"

reviewText:
DreadOut is a survival horror game that combines Indonesian folklore with gameplay mechanics similar to the Fatal Frame series.

The game begins with a high schooler named Linda who's group gets separated from the rest of her school during a fieldtrip. Linda, her classmates and teacher arrive at a mysterious village. Linda and the others find themselves trapped in the village with no other option but to continue onwards. The story takes place in the aforementioned village, an old school, and a mansion.

The most frustrating aspect of DreadOut is how unclear the objectives are. The objectives are most vague and rarely offer any helpful direction or advice to advance in the game. Most of the game time logged in the game will be trying to figure out the puzzles and how to advance to the next section.

Whilst it is not the most graphically impressive game, DreadOut makes up for that with an interesting story and setting. If DreadOut had a bigger budget, this game could have been even more brilliant.

Regardless of the faults, DreadOut is a game that all fans of horror ought to try.
